column1: McCain is a strong proponent of Free trade.Free trade He supports the Free trade (NAFTA), the existing Free trade, and U.S. participation in the Free trade (WTO).Free trade He opposes including labor and environmental conditions to trade agreements.Free trade
column3: Obama supports expanding trade only if the United States' trade partners place labor and environmental standards on their industries to "level the playing field" for American interests. If elected President, Obama plans to renegotiate NAFTA to include stricter labor and environmental standards for Canada and Mexico. He has criticized the current agreement for not including such standards, and he also voted against and criticized the Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) for similar reasons.Central America Free Trade Agreement

column2: Barr's campaign site states that America "should encourage private involvement around the world, particularly through free trade. The most effective way to preserve peace is through an expanding free market, backed by a full range of cultural and other private relationships".[33]
column3: McKinney stresses enacting laws on US corporations to keep labor standards high at home and raise them abroad. She would repeal NAFTA (North American Free Trade Agreement), CAFTA, the Caribbean FTA, and US-Peru FTA. She opposes the guest-worker program as riddled with abuses; supports justice for immigrant workers, and immigrant reform that includes amnesty and a path to legalization for undocumented people who have been living and working in the US for years.North American Free Trade Agreement
column4: Nader views NAFTA and the WTO as subverting national regulatory agencies. He blames them for diminishing standards of living (i.e. Race to the bottom). Nader supports a constitutional amendment asserting the "sovereignty of people over the power of corporations."Race to the bottom
